Post Text: A learning perspective regarding the trending  post about Syndicators and LP investing. I have read several posts and their back and forths comments. The most viral and vocal of them came from Judah Aderet Shimshi Kronglas Joseph Kahn and Eli Fried. LinkedIn has limits on characters in a post so I won‚Äôt be repeating it all here :)At the root they have amazing points and sentiments. The goal of this post is to share four concepts that we can all actually learn from and apply to future investments, and quite frankly, every business relationship we get involved with. 1. Investing with a trustworthy and quality syndicator is more important than a better deal. A bad deal with a good syndicator can potentially be saved. A good deal with a bad syndicator almost never works out. 2. My Dad always said that a person can deal with anyone if they know what they are advance. Spend a lot of time doing due diligence on the person and then make sure the agreement addresses any and all concerns that you heard. 3. Everybody has ulterior motives!! It is important that your motives align. A deal isn‚Äôt bad because a syndicator takes a huge upfront fee or a huge promote. Obviously, all else being even you want a syndicator that takes less all around. Sometimes a deal seems like a homerun and the syndicator wants, and IMHO is entitled to, more than the norm. However, if the LP is looking for a long term deal with upside then for that deal they should be investing with a syndicator that puts their fees towards the backend - even if the syndicator is taking a higher than normal split. 4. Our job is to do the hishtadlus (inputs) and God takes care of the success and outputs. Rabbi Berel Wein said (this quote is old as it uses the multiple of rent analogy instead of cap rate but still stands) a person that paid 12x rent and then the market crashed is just as smart as the person that paid 7x and sold for 9x. The difference is the Mazal of when God said the game is over. To trash a syndicator solely based on taking a floater is wrong. A value added deal that had major short term upside warranted a floating rate with a cap which most syndicators took. No one could‚Äôve predicted when the music was going to stop. Stop the hating and share the love!Have an amazing weekend and for those that observe, a great Shabbat!

Post Text: Prediction: SFR and Airbnb Owners Will Start Selling Like Crazy and causing home values to drop even more!For the same root reason as the article points out, I predict that many single-family rental (SFR) and Airbnb owners will start selling like crazy and directly to end users.Real estate used to be about bricks and mortar and slow and steady wealth building. However, over the last 25 years, and especially in the last 7 years, with the advent of technology, social media, and real estate becoming an accepted investment asset, it has turned into a financial engineering mechanism that saw values rise as interest rates dropped and rents increased faster than inflation.On the commercial and multifamily side, which is much more driven by the above factors and where almost all buyers are real estate investors, we are now seeing lower values and much less deal volume as rent growth slows and interest and cap rates rise.On the 1-4 side, you have end users like you and me who buy because we want to live here, not because it is a good investment, plus investors who buy to get a good cash-on-cash return plus the big pop when they sell.As such, what used to be fix-and-flips to end users turned into fix-and-flips to investors and end buyers.However, now that home values seem to be flat and maybe trending down, these investors realize that they are at the peak from a cash flow and value perspective. If rents stay flat, then every new capital expense affects the bottom line and they won't be able to make it up when they sell since the pricing is flat. This cycle will cause more SFR investors to start selling, which will also affect the total number of Airbnb rentals available as their revenues should potentially drop.On the positive side, those that do still hold on as rentals might get a little higher rents than now, but that won't help the values when they sell.What do you think?#RealEstate #HousingMarket #SFR #Airbnb

Post Text: My Three Criteria For Success in Early-Stage Companies(The third one will surprise you!)This is from an email I received this morning from Marc Randolph. Absolutely a jem! Would love your thoughts in comments. I‚Äôve been a part of starting six companies. I‚Äôve mentored several dozen founding teams.  I‚Äôve invested in more than 100 early-stage companies, and I‚Äôve heard countless pitches.  All of that has given me a finely tuned sense of the factors that really matter for the success of an early-stage company. Here are my top three (in order): 1. The Team2. The Team3. The Team  Hopefully this comes as no great surprise (well, maybe that third one does). And if it does, then let me explain for a minute why your team matters more than everything else combined.  When you‚Äôre in your early stages, there are a lot of unknowns, and plenty of elements that are guaranteed to change. Your initial product is just a hunch, you don‚Äôt have product/market fit, and you‚Äôre basically guessing about pricing, go-to-market, and customer type. Eventually, you‚Äôre going to realize that the only constant is your team.  What really matters at this stage isn‚Äôt what you‚Äôre making, or how well-funded you are. Instead, it‚Äôs all about execution, flexibility, and persistence. And that all depends on the quality of your team.  Not only that, but you‚Äôll also realize that employee talent works on a power-curve: the best people are not just marginally better than average‚Ä¶they are many orders of magnitude better. So while my ‚ÄúTop Three‚Äù list is obviously tongue-in-cheek, my belief in the importance of talent isn‚Äôt. And if you‚Äôre curious, I‚Äôve put together another (more genuine) list, of the Top Six Ways I go about attracting and retaining the best possible talent:  1. Interview for what you expect someone to accomplish for you, rather than just reviewing what they accomplished elsewhere. My friend Patty McCord used to suggest picturing what every new hire will have accomplished a year from now, then imagining all the things they would have to do‚Äîand the skills they would need‚Äîto get there. 2. Be thoughtful about why someone may want to come work for you. The best people are not motivated by money, title, or perks. They want to be excited about what they are building and the role they will play in building it. 3. Exceptional people put a premium on working with other exceptional people. This requires that you not only hire well, but cut smartly. It means taking the ‚Äúno jerks‚Äù policy seriously, even for high-performing jerks.  4. A high-performing team needs a manager that they respect. A good manager‚Äôs job is not to make decisions for their team (or worse, review decisions). It‚Äôs to make sure that the right people are in the right seats, and that everyone has the information and context to make great decisions on their own. And after that, their job is to clear away roadblocks.Last two in comments.
